content.description: Moving to and through the second clip was cruxy!  And, up around the 7th bolt was sketch.  Great route.  Marty gives this one three stars.  I agree.
content.protection: Nine bolts to a two shut anchor.
content.location: Near the center of King Dome proper.  Just right of a right-facing dihedral.  Single rope rap.

content.description:
The start was difficult, but the route is continuous.  Holds appear after the first few bolts. Fun slab climbing.  Nice route.  Marty gives this route two stars. 

  I only climbed (most of)the first pitch, so I suspect that I will have to update this with additional info later!  We set up a top rope using the anchors above "From dimples to pimples".
content.protection: Bolted; 9 bolts to a two shut (bomber) anchor.
content.location: Roughly in the center of King Dome proper.

climbs.name: The Rack
climbs.fa: Richie Eastman, Phil Falcone, & Ted Olsen

content.description: Getting established onto the face is the crux of this climb too.  Moreover, the first bolt is very high off the ground, making it scary.  And, as with IM, a manzanita blocks the start.  Bring a hand saw IF you want to do this route.
content.protection: Three bolts.  No Anchor.  Again, we used a tree to belay from.
content.location: Second from the right on the lower face below King Dome proper.

climbs.name: Iron Maiden
climbs.fa: Phil Falcone, Ted Olsen, & Richie Eastman

content.description: The start - getting onto the face - is the crux.  This climb seems harder than an 8 because of the start.  The climb lets off after 10 feet or so.  An overgrown manzanita at the base of this route needs pruning!
content.protection: Three bolts.  No anchor.  We belayed off of a tree
content.location: On the lower face, below King Dome proper, this route is the furtherest right climb.  Easy to get to

climbs.name: Perfect Victim
climbs.fa: Richie Eastman, Phil Falcone, & Ted Olsen

content.description: I thought the crux was between the first and second bolts but it is sustained for at least three bolts.  This is a very good route.  I had fun; the bolts are close enough to feel safe and the first clip is close enough to the ground.
content.protection: Six bolts.  Two hangers at the overhang at the top of the climb can be used to lower or to belay.
content.location: Third route from the right on the lower face below King Dome proper.  Get a $ 2.00 guide produced by Marty Karabin.

content.description: The start of the climb is likely the crux.  A few burley moves gets you established into the crack. Not much traffic on this climb; I was crumbling rock off in my hands.  But, I liked the first 50 feet of this climb.  It needs cleaning up, but it was fun.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a # 4 camalot.
content.location: Second route from climbers left on the lower face below King Dome proper. This hand crack has a shrub growing out of the crack about 30 feet up.

content.description: Near the top of the dihedral was cruxy, and so was passing the first bolt.  This mixed route gets your heart rate elevated!
content.protection: Small to medium cams and a set of nuts.  Five bolts gets you to the (bomber) anchors
content.location: This route is also near the center of the King Dome.  The start of this route is the right-facing dihedral.

content.description:
Wonderful granite.  Mostly south facing walls.  Single and multi-pitch climbs.  The bolted routes that we got on were fun.  Moreover, the hangers were reasonably well spaced.  This promises to be a very cool crag when it gets hot in the Valley. 

  This area should be considered an adventure crag, both because of the 20 plus miles (over 26) of gravel road and the: 1) steep (arduous) approach or, 2) the 4wd road that brings you to near the top of the crag. 

  You can count on, roughly, two and a half hours from Phoenix to the parking for this area.
